div.p: Xenobiology (XB) aims to design biological systems endowed with unusual biochemistries, while enzymology concerns the study of enzymes, the workhorses of biocatalysis. Biocatalysis employs enzymes and organisms to perform useful biotransformations in synthetic chemistry and biotechnology. During the past years, the effects of incorporating noncanonical amino acids (ncAAs) into enzymes with potential applications in biocatalysis have been increasingly investigated. Here we provide an overview of the effects of new chemical functionalities that have been introduced into proteins to improve various facets of enzymatic catalysis. We also discuss future research avenues that will complement unnatural mutagenesis with the standard protein-engineering toolbox for producing novel and versatile biocatalysts with applications in synthetic organic chemistry and biotechnology.

div.head: Biocatalysis and directed evolution
div.p: Humankind has traditionally used enzymes and microorganisms in common chemical biotransformations relevant to baking, brewing and other fermentation processes. Modern biocatalysis produces chemicals with high added values including medicines, vitamins, food ingredients, additives, biofuels, fragrances, polymers and many other useful products. [1] Currently, biocatalysis has become a priority in the chemical industry. Its importance can be historically documented in three research waves, which are summarized in Fig. 1. [2] In the first wave, which dates back to more than a century ago, it became possible to scientifically articulate the fact that living organisms catalyze useful biotransformations, and subsequently apply whole cells and celluar extracts for the production of chemicals. [3] At this stage biocatalysts still suffered from a substrate scope limited to natural substrates. During the second wave (1970s-1980s), the first proteinengineering methods were developed, which enabled the overexpression and isolation of enzymes to better control both the quality and quantity of the biocatalyst. [2,4] However, significant issues of enzyme stability and their limited substrate scopes especially towards nonnatural substrates were still a bottleneck. In the third and current wave (since the 1990s), which started with the pioneering work of Stemmer [5] , Arnold [6] , Reetz [7] and Bornscheuer [8] many of the previous problems have been solved by directed evolution. Directed evolution consists of iterative rounds of gene mutagenesis, followed by screening (or selection) where the generated enzyme mutants are evaluated based on their performance in model reactions. This method is commonly used to improve protein activity, binding, allostery, substrate scope, enantioselectivity and stability, among other properties. [1a, 1g, 1h, 7, 9] Moreover, directed evolution along with computational chemistry enables the creation of de novo designed enzymes to access non-natural transformations including the Kempelimination [10] , Diels-Alder [11] and retro-Aldol [12] reactions, which previously belonged exclusively to synthetic chemistry laboratories. [13] Directed evolution is nowadays one of the most powerful approaches in protein engineering, yet it is limited to the 20 canonical amino acid (cAA) building blocks. In the past decade, the field of xenobiology (XB), and, in particular, the subfield of genetic-code reprogramming, has developed rapidly to allow the efficient introduction of hundreds of noncanonical amino acids (ncAAs) and prosthetic groups into protein structures. [14] In this regard, the fundamental question is whether proteins, particularly enzymes, remain functional or even have their catalytic properties improved with newly added chemistries such as unnatural cofactors and ncAAs. In this review, we summarise the advances in this research area and discuss the potential of unnatural building blocks in biocatalysis. The regio-and stereosectivity of the newly introduced hydroxylßgroups are marked in red on the presented structures. The first engineering wave started early in the last century when it was realized that whole-cell or cell lysates from organisms such as fungi could catalyze important chemical biotransformations like steroid hydroxylation. [3] In the second wave, the rise of molecular biology and employment of tools in microbiology enabled a more precise control of protein function, as exemplified by the site-directed mutagenesis of a mouse CYP for the hydroxylation of steroids. [4] At the beginning of the third wave, control over stereo-and regioselectivity via directed evolution was achieved, as illustrated by the ISM-based CASTing of Cytochrome P450 derived from Bacillus megaterium (P450BM3) towards testosterone hydroxylation. [15] Currently, the third wave is dedicated to the optimization of virtually any biocatalyst to fit the process specifications, as well as the creation of enzymes that do not exist in nature using de novo design and directed evolution. ISM [16] : iterative saturation mutagenesis; CAST [17] : combinatorial active site saturation test; B-FIT: B-factors iterative test; ProSAR: statistical analysis of protein sequence activity relationships [18] ; MDs: molecular dynamics simulations; QM/MM: quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics; SPI: Selective-pressure incorporation and SCS: Stop codon suppression of ncAAs: non-canonical amino acids.

div.head: Xenobiology with a focus on protein reprogramming
div.p: Nature uses a very limited set of chemicals when compared to the exceptionally rich and wide synthetic organic chemistry repertoire. [19] This fact precludes a wide range of (bio)chemical transformations and their biotechnological applications. The emerging field of XB [20] aims to fill this gap by designing biological systems endowed with a chemistry absent in natural organisms. [21] XB is highly diverse, with various emerging research directions. [22] The first direction encompasses the development of alternative nucleic acids (xenonucleic acids, XNAs) based upon new base pairs, sugars and backbones. A particular goal of this research is to provide different or additional letters to the existing genetic code [23] . [24] Another XB research direction is based on the concept of biocontainment, first proposed by Marliere and Herdewijn [25] and further elaborated by Schmidt, de Lorenzo and Budisa. [21,26] Biocontainment implies that a synthetic organism can only survive in natural environments by using a human-supplied synthetic building blocks that has no biochemical source otherwise. [27] Ravikumar and Liu recently highlighted the latest studies on biocontainment [28] based on two recent reports by Church [29] and Isaacs [30] . Similarly, Budisa and Süssmuth just reported an alternative approach towards biocontained cell factories. [31] These approaches are tightly bound to the third XB research direction, which aims to explore the impact of new chemical functionalities in proteins and proteomes. [32] Organic chemistry can provide a great diversity of noncanonical amino acids (ncAAs) and unnatural cofactors that can be introduced into microorganisms as building blocks by experimental evolution. For example, E. coli was recently evolved to recruit thienopyrrole instead of indole and affords complete tryptophan substitution with thienopyrrole-alanine (Fig. 2) [33] in the genetic REVIEW code (Fig. 3). Fluorinated amino acids have been also used to engineer the proteomes of E. coli [34] and B. subtilis. [35] For a comprehensive analysis of these studies the reader is further referred to the contemporary literature. [14a, 14c, 36] Figure 2. Tryptophan has been recently substituted by thieno [3,2]pyrrolealanine in the E. coli proteome. All the developments in the third XB direction confronted us with the fundamental question whether proteins, in particular, enzymes, remain functional or even improve their catalytic properties with newly added chemistries such as unnatural cofactors and ncAAs. An analysis of this issue is provided later in section 3.

div.head: NcAAs
div.p: The incorporation of ncAAs into proteins has become a rich field of research that has contributed to a better understanding of many biological phenomena and processes. [37] The interdisciplinary nature of this research will enable the acceptance of a uniform terminology. [21,38] NcAAs can be defined as amino acids that are not genetically encoded by natural living beings. For this reason, they are also known as non-proteinogenic [39] or unnatural amino acids. [14b] However, the term noncanonical encompasses in a more general way all those amino acids of natural (terrestrial and extraterrestrial) or synthetic (i.e. man-made or anthropogenic) origin that are excluded from the canonical genetic-encoding mechanism. [14e] NcAAs used in XB are ideally divided in two main classes: those structurally similar to cAAs are called analogues whereas those that highly differ from canonical structures are dubbed as surrogates. [40] NcAAs enable the manipulation of protein structures with unprecedented precision at the single-atom level. Such "atomic mutations" (e.g. S→CH2 or H→OH) are easily performed when replacing a cAA by an analogue that differs only slightly in the side-chain. [41] Likewise, elements normally missing in cAA side chains can be substituted, for instance, Se in place of S or F (and the other halogens) in place of H, redox-sensitive groups and heavy atoms. [14a, 42] In addition, new molecular fragments or electron withdrawing/donating substituents like nitro-(NO2) or methoxy-groups (OCH3) for tuning redox-reactions can be introduced. [43] In particular, small-sized ncAAs prone to very rapid chemoselective reactions [44] are especially attractive as tags for various biological applications. [45] Perhaps, the most simple and popular example is the terminal alkyne and organic azido pair that provides suitable bioorthogonal reactive handles for click-chemistry. [46] This reaction enables screening for various specific protein-protein interactions as well as performing protein-immobilization or site-specific derivatization of proteins with synthetic moieties such as polyethylene glycol molecules, sugars, oligonucleotides or fluorophores. [47] Furthermore, ncAAs containing UV-sensitive groups allow specific transformations such as controlled release of the functional moieties from so-called photo-cages, induction of interactions by photoreactive groups and conformational changes by photoswitches. [14g, 48] In molecular and cellular biology, ncAAs have proven useful to study protein behavior with much higher accuracy than before. [49] In particular, it is possible to study protein conformation by Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) [50] and to follow intracellular protein localization (using ncAAs as fluorophores) [48] or to determine protein structures in vivo by means of 3D X-ray crystallography (using ncAAs carrying heavy atoms) or 19 F-NMR (using fluorine-labelled ncAAs). [51] This provides valuable chemical information that can be used to optimize or even uniquely redesign or stabilize biocatalysts. [52] However, it should always be kept in mind that the incorporation of ncAAs can alter the biophysical and biochemical properties of proteins such as pKa [53] , hygroscopy [54] , polarity [55] , stability [56] and spectroscopic properties [40,57] .

Proteins containing ncAAs are named alloproteins [58] or xenoproteins [59] (and allo-/xenoenzymes, accordingly). They are mainly produced by two different strategies, whose choice highly depends on the structure of ncAAs to incorporate. Indeed, current microbiological methods limit which of these can be incorporated. Both currently used methods are based on 'misacylation' of transfer RNA (tRNA) with ncAAs (see Scheme 1). One strategy exploits mischarged native tRNAs and aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases (AARSs) from the organisms chosen as protein expression hosts, whereas the other method relies on so-called 'orthogonal pairs' (o-pairs) composed of tRNAs and AARSs that suppress stop codons and usually originate from evolutionarily distant organisms. [60]

div.head: SPI: protein reprogramming using native tRNAs and AARSs
div.p: The simplest approach for incorporating ncAAs into proteins is via selective pressure incorporation (SPI). [61] Although the historical roots of this method date back to the 1950s (see early
10.1002/anie.201610129 Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

review by Richmond [62] ). it became popular after an early selenomethionine (Sem, Fig. 4) incorporation experiment of Cowie and Cohen [63] , which was rediscovered by protein crystallographer W. A. Hendrickson in 1990's. [64] Later, the potential of SPI in protein engineering was independently recognized by the Budisa [14a] and Tirrell [38b] labs (Scheme 1A).

Firstly, a bacterial culture is grown in minimal medium with a limited amount of the cAA to be replaced. After cAA depletion, the desired ncAA is added to the medium along with a specific inducer (e.g., IPTG) for overexpressing the target gene. Optimized fermentation and recombinant expression usually yield a high-level of cAA→ncAA substitution. [38a] Of course, the microbial strain should not be able to produce the target cAA metabolically (akin to essential amino acids in humans), i.e., it should be an auxotrophic strain. SPI enables incorporation of analogues that are structurally similar to their cAA counterparts, because these must be up-taken by native cell-membrane transporters and processed in the protein translation machinery. Upon entering the cell, the endogenous AARS loads these ncAAs onto the "cognate" tRNA molecules. Consequently, the target cAA is globally replaced by the analogue during xenoprotein biosynthesis. Scheme 1. Methods for incorporating ncAAs into proteins. A) The selective pressure incorporation (SPI) method exploits the endogenous translational machinery to load ncAAs onto cognate tRNAs prior to protein overexpression. B) The stop codon suppression (SCS) approach endows the host with a new orthogonal aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase (AARS) and suppressor tRNA (AARS:tRNA sup ) pair (o-pair) to introduce a given ncAA at one or more locations in a target protein. The o-pair originates from natural sources and can be adjusted for the specific incorporation of the desired ncAA surrogate structure using positive and negative genetic selection procedures. [42a] The SPI method is straightforward because it does not alter the native cellular translational components, rather, it exploits the relative promiscuity of AARSs [65] . For example, Szostak and coworkers found that more than 50 analogues can be enzymatically charged onto "cognate" tRNAs. [66] They concluded that ~70% of codons (Fig. 3) can be reassigned by exploiting the substrate tolerance of AARSs. [67] This so-called "poly-substrate specificity" is also a feature of many orthogonal AARSs (vide infra). [68] With SPI, multiple variants of the same protein can be produced by feeding the culture with different analogues. Because 30-40 sense codons are sufficient to encode the genetic information of an organism, a large number of sense codons (>20) may be available for recoding with ncAAs. [69] Although this method can provide proteins containing analogues of virtually any cAA, the most dramatic effects (either favorable or detrimental) arise with substitution of cAAs that are critical for function and folding (e.g., Pro, Met, His or Trp).

div.head: SCS: Protein reprogramming using orthogonal pairs
div.p: Due to its simplicity, SPI was initially the method of choice for producing xenoproteins, but the need for an alternative method to incorporate other ncAAs clearly emerged. Since the natural AARS:tRNA pairs discriminate between amino acids based on their structure, much effort was directed to develop novel AARS:tRNA pairs that could recognize ncAAs with structures very different from the 20 cAAs. Nature itself uses some amino acids outside of this set that can be genetically encoded into proteins, such as N-formylmethionine, selenocysteine and pyrrolysine (Sec and Pyl, respectively; see Fig. 3).

Due to their rare appearance in proteins from specific organisms, Sec and Pyl are classified as special canonical amino acids. [58] Although, their decoding mechanisms are quite different [70] , these natural orthogonal incorporation systems can be taken as the starting points to engineer stop codon suppression (SCS, Scheme 1B). In the case of Pyl, for instance, the AARS and of the corresponding tRNA should be modified by creating AARS libraries in which the enzyme active site is engineered via directed evolution. By using genetic methods, a mutant enzyme that specifically recognizes a given ncAA structure can be isolated (black box, Scheme 1B). The novel AARS will thus not interfere with the translation of cAAs. The desired ncAA must be charged exclusively onto its cognate tRNA, whose anticodon has been ensured to correspond to a special codon (e.g., in E. coli the least used amber stop codon UAG). This approach would then create a site-specific incorporation of ncAA at the genetically predefined positions in the target sequence (e.g. an in-frame stop codon), in contrast to SPI where the replacement occurs in a residue specific manner.

The mutated tRNA is referred to as the suppressor tRNA (tRNAsup) and it should not act as a substrate for any of the 20 canonical AARSs. Therefore, the combination of an engineered AARS and its tRNAsup is what is called an orthogonal pair (opair). Not only the Pyl incorporation system, but also AARS:tRNA pairs of organisms evolutionary distant [71] from the expression hosts (i.e., from other domains of life) have been used as starting platforms for the directed evolution of new opairs. The most used systems for SCS in E. coli are the o-pairs derived from tyrosine of the archaeon Methanocaldococcus jannaschii (TyrRS:tRNA Tyr ), pyrrolysine of the archaeon Methanosarcina species (PylRS:tRNA Pyl ) as well as phenylalanine of the baker's yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae (PheRS:tRNA Phe ). [14f] In recent years, numerous ncAAs have been site-specifically incorporated into proteins using a wide range of expression hosts including bacteria, yeasts, and mammalian cells [60] , and even multicellular organisms like the worm Caenorhabditis elegans [72] and the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. [14d, 73] The engineering of orthogonal pairs based on Sec incorporating machinery appears to be far more complex and thus it still remains a challenge for contemporary research. [74] Both the SPI and the SCS methods have advantages and disadvantages, and these are summarized below.

div.head: SPI vs. SCS method
div.p: The existence of two methods in XB determines the limits for the set of ncAAs that can be ribosomally inserted into proteins. The choice of the method is not trivial and requires a number of considerations that should be taken into account:

SPI employs native expression systems readily available in the organism, whereas SCS uses non-native o-pairs, which often require laborious optimization to achieve optimal specificity (usually via directed evolution).

SPI allows the simultaneous incorporation of multiple ncAAs into the same protein. This number is limited only by the number of amino acid auxotrophies in the strain. [53b] Proper metabolic configuration of the expression host is essential to achieve full ncAA labelling. [75] In the case of SCS, the current development of the method allows for one or a few ncAA structures to be incorporated into one protein sequence. [76] 3) SPI does not increase the amino acid alphabet size, thus one ncAA replaces one cAA. In contrast, in SCS the ncAAs are added to the 20 cAA repertoire. For this reason SCS is often referred to as genetic code expansion. [14b] 4)

SPI performs global ncAA incorporation, i.e., it is not possible to choose target cAA positions for substitution; thus, it represents residue-specific incorporation. [14a] Conversely, SCS allows the site-specific incorporation of ncAAs at virtually any position defined by insertion of a stop codon via mutagenesis. [60] 5)

SPI is restricted to a pool of ncAAs that are similar to the initial cAAs (analogues). SCS allows for the incorporation of a variety of surrogates that are distinctly different from the 20 cAAs, but it is limited by the availability of suitable o-pairs and tolerance of the translation machinery components. [76] 6) SPI requires strict fermentation conditions (time and medium composition), while there is no medium limitation for SCS. However, in this case the cell viability can be affected by the interference with some important stop codons in the genome. This as well as competition with release factors (RFs) for the stop codons and so-called "context effects" (vide infra) can lead to reduced protein yields with the SCS method.

Although, an auxotrophic strain is used in the SPI method, alternative metabolic sources of cAAs (e.g. protein recycling, salvage pathways) are not always excluded. This provides a source for the cAA contamination in the produced protein. In the SCS method, the source of heterogenicity is often presence of natural suppressors (Tyr, Gln, Leu, etc.).

Importantly, the SPI and SCS methods can be combined for the production of the very same xenoprotein. [77] Such simultaneous substitution has been demonstrated, in particular by global replacement of Met/Pro using SPI [53b] and Asp/Asn substitution with suitable amino acid surrogates via SCS on model proteins expressed in E. coli. [78]

div.head: Strain and ribosome engineering: recent developments
div.p: Competition between release factor proteins (RFs) and misacylated tRNAs for the suppression of stop codons is the main cause of low protein yields and reproducibility that accompanies the SCS method. [76,79] This issue has been addressed by the Sakamoto [80] , Wang [81] and Church/Isaacs [82] groups who created robust E. coli strains lacking release factor 1 (RF1), the main amber stop codon suppressor. These strains were used to produce recombinant proteins containing single and multiple ncAAs via SCS method in higher yields. Yet the empirical observations suggest the existence of so-called mRNA "context effects" [83] in SCS. These are practically manifested as low yields of target proteins and truncated products even if the efficiency of ncAA incorporation is believed to be improved with RF-free engineered strains. [84] Recently Ignatova and others provided an experimental description and conceptual framework for understanding these phenomena. [85] In other words, the insertion of a stop codon in a particular sequence can cause large deviations from natural mRNA folding and subsequently affect the binding site interaction strength within the ribosome. [86] These SCS issues could be remediated by applying computational design to the mRNA sequences. About a decade ago, Tirrell and co-workers proposed to use incorporation of ncAAs at rare sense codons [87] as an alternative to SCS. In this sense, we and others addressed the degeneracy of the genetic code and attempted to improve ncAA incorporation by emancipating rare sense codons from their prior coding roles and reprogramming them to permanently code for certain ncAAs. [36f, 87a] Scheme 2. In vivo metabolic production of the ncAA Aha in E. coli. [88] One challenging task in SPI experiments is to achieve a high intracellular concentration of the ncAA and at the same time depletion of the proteinogenic cAA to be replaced, without compromising cell viability. Also, ncAA supply may become expensive as the xenoprotein expression process scales up. A solution to this issue comes from recent advances in metabolic 10.1002/anie.201610129 engineering.

For instance, Ma et al. engineered azidohomoalanine (Aha) production in a methionine (Met) auxotrophic E. coli strain by feeding it with O-acetyl-homoserine and inorganic azide for recombinant xenoprotein expression (Scheme 2). [88] Although chemical synthesis is still the main source of ncAAs, their market availability, price and purity are serious bottlenecks for industrial biotechnology. A more useful, broadly applicable chemical handle would be an ncAA that is intracellularly produced from low-cost chemical precursors added to the growth medium. For example, Exner et al. [44] reported very recently an engineered PylRS varinat capable of activating and tRNA charging with S-allylcysteine (Sac) generated in situ from a cheap precursor allyl mercaptan, using the cysteine biosynthesis pathway. The biological abundance and biosynthetic production pathway of Sac greatly reduces the cost of protein production, potentially making industrial-scale applications feasible.

div.head: New chemical functions: what have we learned?
div.p: During the last three decades, several groups have considered the incorporation of ncAAs, mainly into enzymes, to study structure-function relationships. [56a, 89] Numerous ncAAs (Fig. 4) have improved various enzymatic properties: turnover number, catalytic efficiency, thermal and chemical stability, substrate scope, enantio-and regioselectivity as well as resistance against inhibition. These are discussed in sections 3.1-3.4. Opportunities for enzyme cross-linking and immobilization (3.5) and the special role of local electric fields in enzyme catalysis (3.6) are then highlighted. Finally, metal coordination effects and the potential of unnatural cofactor constructs (3.7) are described. Different aspects of these topics have been reviewed recently.

[89a, 89e, 89f, 90] Herein, we provide a complete overview of all these topics from a chemical perspective by focusing on the roles and effects of ncAAs on biocatalyst function. In addition, in Appendix we provide a comprehensive survey (Table 1) of the features of enzyme variants engineered with ncAAs. The numerals following the abbreviated ncAA names indicate the relevant subsections of part 3 of this review: 1, activity, including turnover number and catalytic efficiency; 2, stability, including extending the storage half-life and resistance to oxidation, organic solvents, denaturants, inhibitors, and heat denaturation; 3, expanding the substrate scope or changing enantio-and stereospecificity; 4, eliminating inhibition mechanisms; 5, inserting reactive groups and bioorthogonal handles useful for surface immobilization; 6, investigation of enzyme electrostatics within protein structures and over the course of catalysis, and; 7, enabling metal-coordination or the binding of unnatural cofactors. See also Table 1.
10.1002/anie.201610129 Angewandte Chemie International Edition REVIEW

div.head: Activity: turnover and catalytic efficiency
div.p: The first goal pursued by enzyme engineering with ncAAs was the improvement of catalytic properties on common model substrates. In many cases, catalytic efficiency (kcat/KM), turnover (kcat) and substrate affinity (KM) are defined by classical enzyme kinetics. [91] Typically studied enzymes are lipases, which catalyze both the hydrolysis of esters and transacylation reactions, finding therefore a large variety of applications. [92] [93] A systematic study using SPI-based engineering was conducted on a lipase from the hyperthermophilic bacterium Thermoanaerobacter thermohydrosulfuricus (TTL) using polyauxotrophic E. coli strains. [94] Five different amino acids (Trp, Phe, Tyr, Met and Pro) were subjected to global replacement by ncAAs. These residues were chosen due to either their presence in the hydrophobic core (Trp, Phe, Met), or their involvement in peptide bond cis-trans isomerization (Pro), or their high concentration in either the substrate binding pocket (Phe, Tyr) or the lid domain that regulates the access of the substrate to the active site (Tyr, Met, Pro). Overall, the substitutions were expected to affect the protein fold and thus to change the temperature dependence of the enzyme activity. Indeed, one important feature of TTL is that the enzyme must be pre-incubated at elevated temperatures to shift its basal catalytic activity to the maximal catalytic activity. This process, known as heat activation, triggers a conformational rearrangement that opens the lid domain on top of the active site. The activity of the wild type (WT) and of the variant enzymes was measured via a spectrophotometric reaction with 4-nitrophenyl palmitate as the model substrate (Scheme 3). Scheme 3. Enzymatic hydrolysis of para-nitrophenyl palmitate used to characterize TTL reaction velocity. The production of para-nitrophenolate can be followed spectroscopically.

The fresh variants harboring para-and metafluorophenylalanine (pFF; mFF, Fig. 4) exhibited already a high fraction of their maximal activity, whereas the WT was only weakly active before heat activation. Especially intriguing was the observation that, after activation, TTL[mFF] is 25% more active than the WT. [94] Another remarkable finding was that replacement of Met by its nonoxidizable analogue norleucine (Nle, Fig. 4) resulted in a fully active variant without heat activation (Fig. 5).

The superfamily of cytochromes P450 (CYP) is another important class of biocatalysts, which catalyze the transfer of an oxygen atom from molecular oxygen (O2) to an organic substrate upon donation of electrons, in most cases obtained from external electron donors, e.g., coenzyme NAD(P)H (Scheme 4). [95] Figure 5. Thermoanaerobacter thermohydrosulfuricus lipase (TTL), its lid domain (cyan) and the 11 Met residues substituted by Nle in the SPI experiment (black). The most prominent feature of the TTL[Nle] variant is a ten-fold higher activity in the absence of heat activation, whereas the WT lipase is almost inactive without thermal treatment. [94a] CYPs can perform a wide range of reactions [93] , thus finding applications in drug development, bioremediation and in the synthesis of fine chemicals, fragrances and other useful compounds. [96] Scheme 4. CYPs act primarily as monooxygenases. Here exemplified with hydroxylation of non-activated C-H bonds. Among all CYPs known, one of the most appealing for industrial applications is the one derived from Bacillus megaterium (P450BM3) because it possesses one of the highest known catalytic turnovers. P450BM3 has been engineered towards a broad range of substrates including alkanes, various drug scaffolds, terpenes and steroids. [1g, 97] The groups of Arnold and Tirrell used SPI to replace Met by Nle in P450BM3 to test whether the enzyme stability was hampered by Met oxidation over the course of the reaction. [98] The peroxygenase activity of the resulting CYP variant was tested on the hydroxylation reaction of para-nitrophen-oxycarboxylate in the presence of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) (Scheme 5); C12 of the substrate is specifically hydroxylated and paranitrophenolate is released, which has an absorption maximum at 398 nm. Although the variant P450BM3[Nle] does not show improved stability, but rather is more thermolabile than the Met parent, it exhibits an almost two-fold increase in catalytic activity compared to the WT enzyme.

Remarkably, Kolev et al. reported a P450BM3 variant that oxidizes (+)-nootkatone (Scheme 6) with the highest turnover number (kcat) reported to date for an engineered CYP on a complex molecule. [99] This was achieved by substitution of Leu75 with para-aminophenylalanine (pAmF, Fig. 4) by SCS in the active site of the enzyme, which resulted in a five-fold increase in the turnover number, whereby the product distribution (90% epoxide) remained the same. Scheme 6. Oxidation of (+)-nootkatone performed by P450BM3.

Glutathione S-transferase (GST) is a detoxification enzyme that conjugates one molecule of glutathione to xenobiotic compounds in order to increase their hydrophilicity and thus facilitate their degradation. Parson et al. replaced four Trp residues of rat M1-1 GST (two located within the active site) by 5-fluorotryptophan (5FW, Fig. 4) via SPI. As a result, a four-fold increase in kcat and a two-fold increase in kcat/KM was observed for the xenoproteins compared to the WT GST. [89a] Dominguez et al. statistically replaced the four Phe residues of the restriction endonuclease PvuII with oFF, mFF and pFF (Fig. 4) using the SPI method. [100] PvuII cleaves DNA in correspondance of CAG|CTG sequences. The PvuII[oFF] and PvuII[pFF] variants had the same specific activity of the WT while PvuII[mFF] variant exhibited two-fold higher activity compared to the WT. Despite the fact that none of the exchanged Phe residues belonged to the active site, the effect on enzyme activity was caused by overall conformational differences between the final folded structures. [100] Transaminases catalyze the transfer of an amino group between amino acids and α-keto acids. They are appealing biocatalysts involved in the production of optically pure α-amines either through chiral resolution of cheap racemic amines or by asymmetric synthesis starting from prochiral ketones. [101] Deepankumar et al. globally replaced Tyr by metafluorotryrosine (mFY, Fig. 4) in ω-transaminase (ω-TA) using the SPI method. [102] The resulting variant ω-TA[mFY] exhibited almost two-fold higher activity than the WT in the conversion of acetophenone into (S)-1-phenylethylamine (Scheme 7) in presence of 20% DMSO. [102] Scheme 7. Transamination reaction performed by ω-TA. [103] For better solubility of the reacting components the residual catalytic activity was monitored in the presence of 20 % DMSO. [102] The Marx group engineered an N-terminally truncated version of DNA polymerase I from Thermus aquaticus (KlenTaq). DNA polymerase I catalyzes 5' → 3' DNA synthesis by selecting nucleotides complementary to the template DNA strand. It also performs proofreading of the newly synthesized DNA and is endowed with exonuclease activity in order to correct nucleotide mismatches. KlenTaq is a highly thermostable polymerase and has no nuclease activity. These two features make it particularly appealing for application in molecular biology. Global substitution of Met with trifluoromethionine (Tfm, Fig. 4) was performed by SPI. The resulting variant retained almost the same activity as the WT at high temperatures (up to 70 °C). [104] In another study from the same group using the same method, the crucial Tyr671 in the KlenTaq enzyme was replaced by 2,3,5-trifluorotyrosine (F3Y, Fig. 4). The substitution dramatically reduced the activity yet it revealed the importance of the pKa of the Tyr residue for H-bond interaction with the target DNA. [105] E. coli nitroreductase (NTR) reduces the nitro group of various compounds. NTR is currently used as a local prodrug activator for cancer therapy, though it has the limitation of a high KM towards the substrate CB1954 (Scheme 8). Structural studies had suggested Phe124 could be critical for the establishment of a π-stacking interaction with the aryl ring of the CB1954 or with the NADH cofactor. Jackson et al. [106] performed replacement of the Phe124 residue in the active site of this enzyme with cAAs (Tyr, Lys and Asp) and with several Phe analogues using the SCS method. The best variant contained para-nitrophenylalanine (pNF, Fig. 4) and showed a more than 30-fold increase in kcat/KM compared to the WT, as well as a more than two-fold increase compared to the most active cAAbased mutant Phe124Lys. Notably, this suggested that πstacking may not be a critical interaction; otherwise the mutant Phe124Tyr should have been the most active. Moreover, substrate binding and catalytic activity was both improved, due to the dipole moment introduced into the ring by the nitro group of pNF.

div.head: REVIEW
div.p: Ugwumba et al. [107] studied substitution of the key Tyr309 of phosphotriesterase from Agrobacterium radiobacter (arPTE) via the SCS method. ArPTE hydrolyses organophosphates (e.g. pesticides) and the target residue was located in the substrate binding site. The arPTE variant containing L-(7hydroxycoumarin-4-yl)ethylglycine (HCEtG, Fig. 4) in place of Tyr exhibited a 8-fold increase in kcat. The effect was found to be due to electrostatic repulsion between the HCEtG side chain and the product, which are both negatively charged.

The Schultz group scanned different positions for ncAA incorporation into TEM-1 β-lactamase by combining the SCS method and a library of aromatic amino acid surrogates. [89e] Incorporation of para-acrylamido phenylalanine (pAcrF, Fig. 4) in place of position Val216 of TEM-1 β-lactamase increased the kcat of cephalexin deactivation, eventually resulting in an eight-fold enhancement in the overall kcat/KM (Scheme 9). Heme peroxidases are able to perform a number of oxydative reactions; in particular, peroxidation of phenols can be performed by ascorbate peroxidase (APX, Scheme 10A). In this enzyme, the iron-heme complex is coordinated by a histidine side-chain, which is further held in place by an aspartate residue. Very recently Green et al. [108] created a mutated APX, with Nmethyl histidine (Nmh) incorporated by SCS [109] in the place originally occupied by the heme-coordinating His163. The variant demonstrated higher catalytic efficiency and longer overall catalytic stability compared to the wild type. These results proved absence of any charge stabilization in the Asp-His fragment (scheme 10B). Clearly, Nmh represents a significant catalytic advantage in course of the repeated catalytic cycles, due to better electron-donative ability, fixed tautomeric state and charge of the imidazole ring. Since His-metal and His-Asp contacts appear frequently in numerous catalytic centers, the application of Nmh may become a key for creation of more active and stable enzymatic centers in the future. Scheme 10. A. Oxydation of Guaiacol by hydrogen peroxide catalysed by ascorbate peroxidase (APX). B. The function of the His-Asp contact in APX was clarified by a His-to-Nmh substitution. [108] The improved enzymatic properties achieved in the mutant illustrate importance of the His tautomeric state and charge in the vicinity of the catalytic center.

div.head: Chemical and thermal stability
div.p: Lipases are widely used for reactions performed in organic solvents or in the presence of various additives. [110] The hydrolytic residual activity of TTL variants obtained by Acevedo-Rocha et al. via SPI [94b] was examined upon treatment with several organic solvents, metal ions, surfactants, inhibitors, protein reducing, alkylating and denaturing agents. Among the most remarkable effects, it was observed that TTL containing the Trp analogues 4-amino-, 4-fluoro, or 7-aza-Trp (4AmW, 4FW and 7AW, respectively, Fig. 4) as well as the Met analogue Aha retained partial activity after treatment with 90% pyridine. The variants containing both enantiomers of the proline analogue 4fluoroproline (4SFP and 4RFP, Fig. 4), performed much better than the WT and than any other variant upon 90% isooctane and tert-butanol treatment. Interestingly, all variants were more active than the WT in presence of tert-butanol with the exception of TTL [Aha].TTL containing (4R)-hydroxyproline (4RHP, Fig. 4) exhibited almost 10-fold higher activity than the WT after incubation with the surfactant CHAPS. TTL[7AW] displayed about two-fold higher activity than the WT upon urea treatment. TTL[4AmW] and TTL[mFF] showed unprecedented resistance against the denaturant guanidinium chloride; additionally, TTL[4SFP] and TTL [mFY] were not inactivated by the protein inhibitor Pefabloc. [94b] A mutant of Candida antarctica lipase B (CalB Asn74Asp) was engineered by globally replacing either Phe, Tyr or Trp residue with pFF, mFY and 5FW (Fig. 4) via SPI. The three variants were less active than the WT but exhibited higher residual activity after several months of storage. [52] The aforementioned transaminase variant ω-TA[mFY] generated by Deepankumar et al. via SPI was more stable than the WT upon exposure to elevated temperatures (up to 70 °C) and cosolvents (e.g., up to 50% DMSO). [102] Later, the authors reported that the SCS-based incorporation of a single 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA, Fig. 4) residue into ω-TA in place of Arg23 allowed surfaceimmobilization and did not impair the stability. On the other hand, SPI incorporation of 4RFP in the same enzyme alone or in combination with site-specific DOPA incorporation dramatically increases the thermostability of the enzyme and enhanced its resistance towards organic solvents. [111] 10.1002/anie.201610129 REVIEW Othake et al. [112] reported the incorporation of 3-chloro-and 3bromotyrosine (ClY and BrY, respectively, Fig. 4) in the place of 7 Tyr residues in GST via SCS method. The GST[ClY] variant exhibited higher thermostability than the WT enzyme. This effect was initially thought to be due to a tighter packing of the protein core in the GST variant, since the halogenated analogues were bulkier than the original Tyr residues. In order to validate this hypothesis, single positions were mutated back to Tyr. Interestingly, the variants containing 6 halogenated positions but having Tyr at the buried position 155 exhibit further improvement of the thermostability, thus suggesting that not all sites were equally permissible to substitution. In the specific case of position 155, residues bulkier than Tyr lead to steric clashes with the surrounding protein environment. Removal of bromination at position 155 elicited heat resistance. Subsequently, both chlorination and bromination at Tyr32 were observed to have an exceptionally favourable effect on thermostability.

According to the previous observations, two new variants were produced with 7 positions halogenated (32 included, 155 excluded). These two new variants recovered specific activity at room temperature (from 60 to 72% of the WT activity in the case of the chlorinated variant and from 47 to 60% for the brominated one), exhibited improved heat resistance (from 11% to 79% residual activity in the case of the chlorinated variant and from 0 to 71% for the brominated one) and 20% increase in stability against chemical denaturation compared to the WT. When examining the three major stabilizing positions (32, 57 and 73) in crystal structures of these variants, it was observed that the halogenated side chains established synergic interaction networks bridged by canonical side chains. In particular, the analogue at position 32 and Tyr56 form a hydrogen bond between their hydroxyl groups, while the analogues at positions 57 and 73 are connected via Asp59. They both form an electrostatic interaction between the hydrogen of their hydroxyl groups and the carboxylic group of Asp, strengthened by halogenation. Since Tyr-side chains are quite abundant in industrially relevant enzymes such as oxidoreductases or in the antigen-binding regions of antibodies, Othake et al. [112] proposed selective bulky halogenation of Tyr positions as a strategy to improve biocatalysts stability. Indeed, these modifications extend the half-life of E. coli azoreductase by 13-fold after heat exposure and cause 2.0 kcal/mol increase in ΔG(H2O). Azoreductases catalyse the reduction of azo groups utilizing NAD(P)H as electron donor and represent enzymes of industrial interest because by reductive cleavage of azo bonds they can decolorize azo dyes into corresponding aromatic amines. [113] Gilles et al. [114] globally replaced Met with Nle in E. coli adenylate kinase (ADK) via SPI. ADK is a phosphotransferase enzyme involved in the regulation of cellular energy metabolism (Scheme 11). ADK[Nle] exhibited a significant increase in resistance against inactivation by hydrogen peroxide in comparison to the WT, while preserving structure and catalytic activity. This classical example validated the logic of Met-to-Nle replacement, where the side-chain containing the thioether group, prone to be oxidized to sulfoxide or even to sulfone [55a] , is replaced by a structurally similar aliphatic analogue. In a similar approach, Snider et al. [115] replaced Cys490 by Sec in the redox center of thioredoxin reductase from Drosophila melanogaster (DmTR). TR provides electrons for the reduction of disulfide bridges in proteins via thioredoxin. This study was inspired by the observation that the orthologous mammalian TR containing Sec is more stable against a broad range of oxidants than DmTR. Indeed, DmTR[Sec] exhibits higher activity than the Cys-containing WT after incubation with various oxidants. This observation appears to contradict the fact that Sec is not resistant to oxidation, in fact it is more oxidation-prone than Cys because of the higher polarizability of the selenium atom compared to sulfur. Nonetheless, Se is also highly nucleophilic and oxidized Sec can be easily reduced back to the active form. This unique redox behavior may explain why nature evolved selenoenzymes to participate in oxidative metabolism.

Hydrogenases represent another enzyme class that profits from the unique physicochemical properties of selenium. Hydrogenases catalyze the reversible oxidation of molecular hydrogen (H2) to protons (Scheme 12A) and are appealing biocatalysts for the development of biofuel-cell technologies. [116] Scheme 12. A) General reaction catalyzed by hydrogenases. B) A typical metal cluster that is found in the active site of this enzyme class.

One of the main limitations of hydrogenases in vitro is the extreme sensitivity of their metal-cluster (Scheme 12B) towards oxygen. Sakai et al. addressed this problem and reported a photocatalytic system employing a naturally occurring Seccontaining hydrogenase able to generate H2 even at atmospheric oxygen concentrations. [117] Parkin et al. [118] demonstrated that the advantage of the [NiFeSe] cluster over [NiFeS] ones lies in the faster kinetics of reductive reactivation of Se-O species in comparison to S-O ones.

In another example, Baker and Montclare performed global incorporation of pFF in S5 phosphotriesterase (PTE) via the SPI method. The study addressed the Phe-rich hydrophobic motifs which support dimerization of the enzyme. [119] The PTE[pFF] variant showed both improved refolding capacity and thermostability, as demonstrated by an increase in the melting 10.1002/anie.201610129 REVIEW temperature. Moreover, the variant retained higher activity than the WT over a broad range of temperatures and was notably still active at 65°C, while the WT was not. This example illustrates that fluorinated ncAAs can be used for enhancing enzyme thermostability.

Similarly, Votchitseva and co-workers [120] demonstrated that the global replacement of Tyr by its monofluorinated analogue mFY in organophosphate hydrolase (OPH) improved protein stability towards high temperature and alkaline pH. Moreover, the pHoptimum of the variant was shifted to more acidic values, conferring a significant catalytic advantage over the WT under acidic conditions. Finally, Montclare and co-workers [121] replaced all 13 leucine (Leu) residues in chloramphenicol acetyl transferase (CAT) by 5,5,5-trifluoroleucine (Tfl, Fig. 4) via SPI. CAT is responsible for inactivation of the antibiotic chloramphenicol, via acetylation (Scheme 13). The variant CAT13[Tfl] was less stable than the WT but only two rounds of random mutagenesis and screening identified a new variant containing 3 Tfl substitutions, which exhibited better thermostability than the WT enzyme. [122] A loss in stability is quite often experienced when many ncAAs are incorporated into a target protein. Nevertheless, Nagasundarapandian et al. [123] designed protein structures that are not perturbed by the incorporation of ncAAs. They chose the green fluorescent protein (GFP) as a model protein, created mutants with increased refoldability and engineered them with the Met analogues Aha, Nle, homopropargylglycine, ethionine and methoxinine (Hpg, Eth, Mox respectively) by SPI. While the variants with GFP native structure were barely fluorescent, those with optimized structures indeed fully restored fluorescence to the level of the WT protein.

div.head: Substrate scope, enantio-and stereoselectivity
div.p: Enzymes are complex macromolecules and even the smallest modification can elicit major variations in the overall system. For this reason, incorporation of ncAAs might affect more enzymatic properties at the same time. It is not rare that upon incorporation of ncAAs that modify activity or stability, also changes in substrate scope, enantio-and stereoselectivity arise.

In the systematic SPI study reported by Hoesl et al. using TTL, among the 13 variants produced, TTL[mFF] exhibited a broader substrate range than the WT enzyme (C6-C10), being active on triglycerides with both long and short fatty acid chains (C2-C18). [94a] The ω-TA[mFY] described by Deepankumar et al. [102] did not differ from the parent enzyme in terms of substrate specificity or enantioselectivity. However, it additionally performed the complete conversion of acetophenone into the chiral amine (S)-1-phenylethylamine, whereas the WT achieved only ~70% substrate conversion (Scheme 7, section 3.1). Kolev et al. [99] tested the incorporation by SCS of 4 ncAAs (paraaminophenylalanine, para-acetylphenylalanine, O-benzyltyrosine and 3-(2-naphthyl)alanine, pAmF, pAcF, OBnY, 2Nal, respectively, Fig. 4) at 11 positions within the active site of a CYP in order to change the regioselectivity for the hydroxylation of (+)-nootkatone (Scheme 6, section 3.1) and (S)-ibuprofen methyl ester (Scheme 14).

div.head: Scheme 14. Hydroxylation reaction performed by CYP on (S)-ibuprofen methyl ester.
div.p: The WT CYP oxidizes a broad range of substrates but has poor selectivity towards the substrate (S)-ibuprofen methyl ester, giving a mixture of products hydroxylated at C1´ and C2´. Conversely, the variants with pAcF in place ofAla78 and 2Nal in place of Ala328 exhibited highly regioselective hydroxylation at C1´ (88%) and C2´ (95%) sites, (in contrast to 62% and 38% of the WT, respectively. Scheme 14). Similarly, the variant with pAcF in place of Ala82 has much higher regioselectivity than the WT for oxidation at position C13´ of (+)-nootkatone (62% vs 4%, Scheme 6). [99] Notably, the CYP variant with pAcF in place of Ala78 performs also the unprecedented oxidation of (+)nootkatone at position C9´ (73% in contrast to 0% of WT, Scheme 6). These results are unmatched by any mutant containing any of the 20 cAAs, thus demonstrating that the sitespecific incorporation of ncAAs into the active site of an enzyme can provide unprecedented solutions to increase the selectivity of catalytic reactions. Diketoreductase (DKR) catalyzes the stereoselective reduction of ketones to chiral alcohols and represents a biocatalyst of industrial interest for the synthesis of active pharmaceutical compounds. Ma et al. [124] demonstrated that Trp222 plays a gatekeeper role, regulating the access of the substrate to the active site of DKR. In order to investigate whether the size of residue 222 influenced substrate enantiotope preference, they incorporated 4 surrogates at that critical position by SCS. The chosen ncAAs para-methoxyphenylalanine, paraphenylphenylalanine, para-cyanophenylalanine and O-tertbutyltyrosine (pMeOF, BiF, pCNF and pBu t OF, respectively, Fig. 4) had increasing molecular volume of the side chain in the order pCNF<Trp<pMeOF <BiF<pBu t OF. The xenoproteins reduced the substrate 2-chloro-1-phenylethanone, giving different enantiomeric mixtures of alcohol products. The WT DKR exhibited rather small enantiomeric excess (ee), whereas the variants with increased bulkiness DKR[pMeOF], DKR [BiF] and DKR[pBu t OF] exhibited higher ee up to 34 with retention of Ma et al. conclusively demonstrated that incorporating ncAAs bulkier than Trp at gatekeeper position 222 drives substrate preference of DKR to the (R) enantiomer, while incorporating smaller ncAAs turns the preference towards the (S) enantiomer. The reason was found in the orientation assumed by the substrate when entering the active site. Trp and bulkier residues induce reduction of 2-chloro-1-phenylethanone with Re-face preference, while in the case of pCNF, Si-face is preferred. [124] Doubtless, it will be interesting to test whether other smaller or larger cAA could outperform any of the ncAAs employed.

div.head: Inhibition
div.p: Rational incorporation of ncAAs into enzyme active sites can modulate the binding of inhibitor molecules. This shown for murine dihydrofolate reductase is involved in purine and pyrimidine metabolism, and its inhibitors target nucleic acid synthesis. Zheng et al. replaced a critical Phe31 residue in the active site of mDHFR with the bulkier surrogates para-bromophenylalanine (pBrF, Fig. 4) and 2Nal via SCS. The remodeled pocket prevented binding of the inhibitor methotrexate (MTX) by steric exclusion while it does not affect binding of the natural substrate dihydrofolate (Scheme 16). [125] Scheme 16. Dihydrofolate reduction to tetrahydrofolate performed by DHFR with the NADPH cofactor. The dissociation constant of the DHFR complex with inhibitor methotrexate is given as KD.

div.head: Bioorthogonal handles
div.p: A technique commonly used in industrial processes for extending the life cycle of biocatalysts is their immobilization on solid surfaces. [126] Conventionally, the surface attachment is conducted via ionic adsorption, van der Waals forces or covalent linkers. [127] The latter offers the highest enzyme recovery rates. However, all traditional immobilization techniques achieve only a statistical orientation of enzymes on the solid support.

Recently, this issue has been addressed by trying to immobilize enzymes via reaction to site-specifically incorporated ncAAs. For instance, Deepankumar et al. [111] were able to immobilize ω-TA transaminase on chitosan and polystyrene beads after incorporation of a single DOPA residue via SCS. The attachment proceeded via affinity adsorption, as DOPA-rich proteins are known to exhibit good affinities to inorganic surfaces due to catechol coordination to metal ions, metal oxides, borates and silicates. [128] A further development of the method implies the use of ncAAs with bioorthogonal reactive side chains. This is a very powerful tool in protein engineering [14f, 129] because it enables specific bioconjugation reactions via click-chemistry, i.e., copper(I)catalyzed azide-alkyne Huisgen cyloaddition (CuAAC). [130] CuAAC has all the necessary features of an ideal click reaction: it is specific, rapid, and compatible with an aqueous environment while offering in a simple set-up high product yields without appreciable side products. [131] Clickable residues provide a great advantage in the immobilization of biocatalysts on solid surfaces because they allow to control which part of the enzyme is directed toward the support and which part is exposed to the reaction solution (Scheme 17A). Catalysis can consequently benefit from a better exposure of the active site. Also, covalent immobilization offers better control of the protein density on the surface. Usually, ncAAs containing azide functions such as para-azidophenylalanine (pAF, Fig. 4) or Aha are incorporated in the target enzyme via SPI or SCS and are then incubated with surfaces endowed with complementary alkyne functionalities. Alkyne-bearing ncAAs such as para-propargyloxyphenylalanine or homopropargylglycine (pPOFand HpG, respectively, Fig. 4) can also serve for functionalization on azide functionalized surfaces.

Wu et al. [132] site-specifically incorporated pPOF at 6 different positions in T4 lysozyme via SCS in a cell-free expression system and subsequently immobilized the variant on superparamagnetic beads via CuAAC. Lysozyme is a glycoside hydrolase that degrades bacterial cell walls and its immobilization on polymers is being tested for the production of antimicrobial materials, e.g., for food packaging. Muriel-Galet et al. [133] adsorbed lysozyme on a polymeric film via carbodiimidemediated conjugation but no improvement in antimicrobial activity was observed compared to the free enzyme. In the case of Wu et al., instead, the most beneficial site-specific orientation generated a variant Leu91pPOF that was significantly (~1.5-fold) more active than both free and randomly immobilized WT enzyme after harsh freeze-thaw treatment and denaturation with urea. However, no data on protein concentration was given, indicating that these results are yet to be confirmed.

Click reactions can be also used to conjugate proteins to hydrophilic molecules that enhance their hydrophilicity, as shown by the Schultz group in a study in which human superoxide dismutase-1 (SOD) was site-specifically PEGylated via SCS. [134] SOD is involved in the inactivation of highly toxic radical oxygen species, such as superoxide anion (O2 •-, Scheme 18). One pAF residue was site-specifically incorporated in place

div.head: REVIEW
div.p: of Trp33 and the enzyme was subsequently incubated with alkyne-bearing PEG reagents. No significant loss of activity of PEGylated SOD in comparison to WT was detected.

Scheme 17. Click chemistry as a method of choice for enzyme immobilization. Schematic representation of ncAAs-containing enzyme immobilization by using A) copper(I)-catalyzed azide-alkyne Huisgen cyloaddition (CuAAC) [132] or B) copper-free click chemistry using aza-dibenzocyclooctyne, X being different heteratoms according to Ref. [135] . Scheme 18. SOD Antioxidant reaction performed by reducing superoxide anion •-) to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).

The was used for PEGylating Candida antarctica Lipase B (CalB) at surface-exposed Aha residues [136] in order to immobilize the enzyme onto polymersome vesicles. [137] Subsequently, CalB[Aha] was conjugated to alkynefunctionalized elastin [HpG], but the variant retained only half of the WT activity. [138] The Kwon lab reported conjugation of biotin to murine DHFR (mDHFR) via CuAAC and subsequent immobilization on streptavidin-coated plates based on SCS. [139] The biotin anchor was added by clicking azido-conjugated biotin to a single residue of para-ethynylphenylalanine (pEtF, Fig. 4), incorporated mDHFR at a exposed to the solvent (in place of Val43). The attachment to the solid support occurred via biotinstreptavidin affinity. The activity of the immobilized enzyme was measured by following the decreasing substrate absorbance at 340 nm (Scheme 16), and no loss of efficiency compared to the soluble enzyme was observed.

The main drawback of CuAAC, however, is the toxicity of copper, which is problematic in downstream applications involving live cells. [131] This is a major bottleneck for the application in biocatalysis and for this reason alternative click-methods are being developed. [140] The group of van Hest, for instance, reported successful conjugation of CalB[Aha] to PEG functionalized with aza-dibenzocyclooctyne (DIBAC) via copperfree (3+2) cycloaddition (Scheme 17B). [135]

div.head: Mapping of local electric fields
div.p: Many enzymes act on their substrates by imposing specific electric fields, or are controlled by the presence of certain external electric fields (e.g., membrane potential). [141] Thus, in contrast to classical structural biology, the arrangement of charged residues, dipoles and water molecules around the active site can be considered in terms of electric fields. This subsequently offers a theoretical approach to the quantitative treatment of protein features that are relevant to enzymatic reactions (Fig. 6). Figure 6. Schematic overview of protein properties that are to a large extent governed by protein electrostatics. [142] Spectroscopy can provide a description of local electric fields. In particular, IR or resonance Raman spectroscopy demonstrate the vibrational Stark effect (VSE) as the result of interaction with the electric fields [143] (Figs. 7 and 8). However, experimental investigations of electrostatic effects in catalytic cycles have suffered from a lack of non-invasive spectroscopic probes. [144] The incorporation of ncAAs with VSE reporter groups (Fig. 7A) via the SCS method was shown in a recent report to meet this need. [145] The IR-label bearing the ncAA is highly sensitive to electric fields and gives a signal in a specific spectral region that does not overlap with intrinsic protein signals (Fig. 7B). [146] The advantage of SCS is the possibility of inserting the ncAA of interest at different specific positions in the target enzyme. This feature represents a substantial advantage over chemical modifications that generally allow the attachment of the VSE reporter only at the solvent exposed positions and may lead to partial denaturation of the target protein under coupling conditions. [147] Pioneering work in the in vitro incorporation of ncAAs for investigating electrostatics was conducted by the Schultz group [148] . When orthogonal pairs became available, SCS was later used to perform site-specific incorporation of paracyanophenylalanine (pCNF, Fig. 4) into the oxygen-binding protein myoglobin (Mb) in place of His64 [149] . pCNF is VSEactive because of its cyano (CN) group; once introduced into the active site of Mb, it proves to be an excellent Stark reporter of ligand binding and local electrostatic environment. For some vibrational modes the frequency changes virtually linearly with the electric field (F). Δµ is a characteristic property of the individual VSE-reporter groups, namely the change in the dipole moment associated with a transition of a vibration. B) Examples of VSE-reporter groups in the side chains of ncAAs. [150] Recently, the Budisa group used the same approach to introduce the Stark active CN group into the N-terminal part of cytochrome c (cyt c) at position Ph36. [144] cyt c is a membraneassociated protein involved in the cellular respiratory chain and previous studies demonstrated that external electric fields, such as those naturally present at cell membranes, modulate electron transfer rates and transient interactions. [151] By using pCNF as a reporter, it was possible to detect the change in oxidation state of the heme group via a long-range modulation of the local electric field in the N-terminal part of cyt c, which is about 9 Å away. [152] The observed long-range electrostatic interaction demonstrates the high sensitivity of the introduced Stark reporter to changes in electrostatics. The redox-state of the heme group had not been sensed before in this manner, not even when a benzonitrile reporter had been attached to the thiol of a [153] Moreover, it could also indicate that the Nterminal region of cyt c is involved in transient interactions with other proteins during cellular processes. cyt c[pCNF] might serve as a model to probe the role of cyt c electrostatics in in vitro catalyzed biotransformations like epoxidations, hydroxylations and demethylations. [154] Scheme 19. Reaction catalyzed by KSI on the substrate 5-androstene-3,17dione and its mimic inhibitor 19-nortestosterone.

The Boxer group also applied Stark spectroscopy to elucidate the role of electric fields in ketosteroid isomerase (KSI) catalysis. [142b] KSI catalyzes the isomerization of 3-oxo-Δ5steroids to their Δ4-conjugated isomers, and its natural substrates bear a Stark active keto (CO) group, which undergoes charge rearrangement during the rate determining isomerization step (Scheme 19).

In this study, 19-nortestosterone was used as a mimic of the substrate 5-androstene-3,17-dione (Scheme 19), that acts as an inhibitor of the KSI. Since it is not converted into product, 19nortestosterone remains in the active site and enables measurement of the electric force. Mutants of the enzyme were created which exert electric fields of different magnitudes on the CO bond of the inhibitor. The kcat of the natural substrate conversion by the WT and the variants was determined. The authors found that the kcat increased proportionally with the magnitude of the electric field exerted by the active site (Fig. 8). Example of electrostatic catalysis. The electric field that results from the organized environment of the enzymes active site (Fenz) reduces the activation barrier (ΔG ‡ ) of the transformation of a keto group to an enol in the substrate, which is the rate limiting step in the double bond isomerization reaction catalyzed by the KSI enzyme (dashed line). [141] µTS and µGS denote the dipole moment of the keto group in the transition and the ground state, respectively.

Moreover, it was calculated that the electric field of KSI contributes to an increase in kcat of 10 5 -fold in this specific reaction, which was further confirmed by a subsequent investigation. [141] [155] These results clearly confirm the previous observation reported by Wu et al. [156] that electrostatics can make a major contribution to kcat, as likewise suggested by theoretical studies. [142a] The mapping of electric fields in enzymes thus can be considered as a promising approach that will complement structural biology and classical enzymology by providing a physicochemical description of enzymatic catalytic sites.

div.head: Unnatural cofactor binding and metalloenzyme function
div.p: Strategies to engineer metalloenzymes either by using unnatural cofactors or ncAAs with novel properties should enable the design of novel classes of artificial metalloenzymes. Proteins designed in this way would be 'best-of-both-worlds' catalysts, since they should combine the reactivity of transition metals from organocatalysis with the regio-and stereospecificity of enzymes. [157] In particular, ncAAs, such as (2,2'-bipyridin-5yl)alanine (BpyA, Fig. 4) provide high metal binding affinity. [158] For example, the Baker group applied computational protein design to determine a suitable location for incorporating the bidentate ncAA ligand BpyA into an artificial metal binding site. The resulting ncAA-engineered scaffold exhibited efficient binding to several divalent metal ions (Co 2+ , Zn 2+ , Fe 2+ , and Ni 2+ ). [159] Such direct binding of the metal ion cofactor to the enzyme scaffold can be as well achieved by inserting ncAAs with reactive bioorthogonal groups which are subsequently used to covalently bind unnatural metal ion cofactors as depicted in Fig. 9. The feasibility of this approach was demonstrated by Yang et al [160] who used the strain-promoted azide-alkyne cycloaddition to conjugate catalytically active bicyclononynecontaining metal complexes to protein scaffolds containing pAF (Scheme 20A).

div.head: 10.1002/anie.201610129
div.p: Scheme 20. Equipping an enzyme or protein scaffold with an extrinsic catalytic activity imparted by an unnatural cofactor. NcAAs introduced in the protein scaffold can be used to A) covalently bind the unnatural cofactors or B) coordinate the metal cofactor. In comparison to the cAAs, ncAAs offer bi-or polydentate ligands, e.g., the bipyridyl containing ncAA (2,2-bipyridin-5yl)alanine.

Recently, the group of Roelfes [161] incorporated BpyA via SCS into a de novo created active site of the transcription factor lactoccocal multidrug resistance regulator (LmrR). Its natural function is binding DNA but the de novo designed active site enables LmrR to take part in catalysis. In particular, the engineered LmrR served as a scaffold to bind Cu 2+ ions and enable an asymmetric vinylogous Friedel-Crafts alkylation (Scheme 20B). However, the engineered LmrR forms the product shown in Scheme 20 without enantiomeric excess. The incorporation of BpyA via SCS into the engineered LmrR allowed forming the product in enantiomeric excess. The LmrR variant with BpyA at position 89 gave the (+)-enantiomer as product, while the variant with BpyA at position 93 formed the (-)-enantiomer in excess (Scheme 21). Thus, it can be assumed that the different locations of the metal ion ligand BpyA in LmrR create different chiral microenvironments for the catalytic reaction, which lead to a change in the enzyme enantioselectivity. This example demonstrates that the protein environment plays a crucial role in regulating the catalytic properties of metalloenzymes. In cases where sequence-function correlations are difficult to explain, ncAAs can be used to investigate the role of particular conserved residues. For example, Berry et al. [162] replaced the equatorial ligand Cys112 in the copper center of azurine, by selenocysteine (Sec, Fig. 3). Azurine is a bacterial protein involved in electron-transfer reactions and the artificial Se-bearing variant exhibited a prominent change in the spectroscopic features when compared to the WT. Thereafter, the role of the axial ligand Met121 was investigated by increasing local hydrophobicity with Sem, Tfm and Nle (Figure 4) based on the logP scale Met<Sem<Tfm<Nle. They found, that higher hydrophobicity at the axial position directly correlates to higher reduction potential, making azurine more prone to acquire electrons. [163] Low and Hill [164] tuned the reduction potential of the hyperthermostable rubredoxin from Pyrococcus furiosis (PfRd) by replacing the conserved Tyr10 by the Phe analogues pFF, pCNF and pNF. Rubredoxin is an electron-transfer protein with an iron center and Tyr10 indirectly interacts with the metal ion via a Cys ligand residue. Increasing the electron-withdrawing effect at the para position (in the following order Phe < Tyr < pFF < pCNF < pNF) linearly decreased the reduction potential, thus making PfRd less prone to acquire electrons.

Many redox enzymes exhibit a conserved covalent Tyr-His cross-link, including the heme-copper oxidase (HCO) that catalyzes the four-electron reduction of O2 to water (Scheme 22) and has potential applications in biofuel cells. [165] The catalytic role of this cross-link was investigated by using a mutant (Phe33Tyr) of Mb as a model protein which, is a heme protein like HCO but lacks the Tyr-His cross-link. Liu and co-workers incorporated the surrogate imi-tyrosine (imiY, Fig. 4) via SCS which mimics the above mentioned cross link. [165] The resulting variant Mb[Phe33imiY] was able to reduce O2 three times faster than the mutant Mb[Phe33Tyr], while releasing at the same time fewer reactive oxygen species (ROS) as side products. These results demonstrate the importance of the cross-linked Tyr-His ligand for the selective reduction of O2 to water. Similar to the above-mentioned investigations, Zhou et al. [166] used Mb as a model to probe the Tyr-Cys cross-link in Thioalkalivibrio nitratireducens cyt c nitrite reductase (TvNiR) that catalyzes the six-electron reduction of nitrite to ammonia The groups of Lu and Wang [158c, 167] chose Mb[Phe33Tyr] as a model to study the role of Tyr in cyt c oxidase (CcO), the last enzyme of the cellular respiratory chain catalysing O2 reduction to water. They created Mb[Phe33Tyr] variants by incorporating the halogenated tyrosine analogues 3-chlorotyrosine, 3,5difluorotyrosine (ClY and F2Y, respectively, Fig. 4) and F3Y via SCS method. These ncAAs were chosen because the pKa of the phenol ring in their side chains is lower than that of Tyr, in the order Tyr>ClY>F2Y>F3Y. [167] Among the resulting variants, the most active was Mb[Tyr33F3Y], improving the WT activity by about 2-fold. Lowering the pKa for Tyr33 increases the protondonating ability and this leads to higher oxidase activity and selectivity towards water production. This was in agreement with the previous hypothesis that Tyr33 was donating protons for the substrate O-O bond cleavage. In a following study [168] , the same residue Tyr33 was further substituted with 3-methoxytyrosine (MeOY, Fig. 4) via SCS method. MeOY has a similar pKa compared to Tyr but a much lower reduction potential. Expectedly, the variant Mb[Tyr33MeOY] displayed a higher oxidase activity than Mb[Phe33Tyr]. These results demonstrated that the catalytic function of this enzyme is strongly regulated not only by the pKa of Tyr33 but also by its reduction potential.

Ribonucleotide reductase (RNR) performs the catalytic reduction of nucleoside diphosphates to 2´-deoxynucleotides for DNA synthesis. Mono-, di-and tri-fluorinated Tyr-analogs (FnY) were incorporated by SCS method in RNR in place of Tyr356 and enabled elucidation of the role of tyrosyl radicals in mechanism and reactivity of this enzyme via electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. [169] Similarly, Phe365 and Phe605 were replaced with fluorinated mono-, diand tri-fluorinated Phe analogs (FnF) (as electron poor) and pMeOF (as electron enriched, Fig. 4) as counterparts for cationπ interaction in the active portion of squalene hopene cyclase (SHC) from Alicyclobacillus acidocaldarius. SHC catalyses the polycyclization of linear molecules of squalene to polycyclic triterpene and its activity was expected to proportionally correlate to the strength of the cation-π interaction. Indeed, the reaction rates decreased by increasing the number of fluorination substituions in the FnF variants while the pMeOF variants showed higher reaction rates than the WT at temperatures below 40 °C. These observations demonstrated for the first time that the cation-π interaction is involved in stabilization of triterpene biosynthetic intermediates. [170] Clearly, orthogonal translation with various metal-binding ncAAs can lead to new xeno/metallo binding sites. [171] These novel metal binding sites allow the binding of alternative transition metals or alternative metal cofactors, the reactivity of which is regulated by the protein scaffold. [172] In an ideal case, artificial metalloenzymes should be capable of incorporating a transition metal obtained from the cellular environment. In this regard protein scaffolds with bidentate metal binding amino acids like bipyridylalanine [173] or DOPA [174] have proved to be very useful tools to improve the scope and control of coordination chemistry of various metal ion/metal cofactor binding centers.

div.head: What are the future directions in biocatalysis?
div.p: Modern biocatalytic processes can substantially profit from the above mentioned developments. Doubtless, directed evolution has proven extremely powerful in providing more stable and selective biocatalysts, and in endowing natural enzymes with specific catalytic features, although being limited to the 20 cAA building blocks provided by natural protein expression systems. However, XB and in particular protein reprogramming with ncAA offers innovative solutions for protein engineering and should complement directed evolution approaches in the future.

The examples selected in this work show that, upon ncAA incorporation, a single or few protein expression experiments are already sufficient to obtain variants with improved features in comparison to the native enzymes. In contrast, directed evolution experiments usually involve screening hundreds or thousands of variants. [175] Moreover, the introduction of new chemical functionalities into proteins offers unprecedented opportunities to expand their properties beyond the 20 cAAs. For example, no natural amino acid was able to outperform the ncAAs in terms of activity and selectivity for the CYP-based hydroxylation of an ibuprofen-derivative (Scheme 14). [99] Similarly, TEM-1 β-lactamase mutants containing cAA could not match the activity of a variant harbouring a ncAA. [89e] Nevertheless, discouraging is the fact that the main achievements have mainly been demonstrated with Phe, Tyr, Pro, Met and Trp non-canonical substitutes (Fig. 4). Of particular interest for the generation of new enzymes might be to replace histidine residues, which are often essential in biological catalysis. Recent excellent example of replacement of His with Nmh [108] seems to be very encouraging (see Scheme 10B). Even methylation of imidayole side chain can change the features of His such as 1) electron donative properties, 2) ability for a proton abstraction, 3) involvement into hydrogen bond networks, 4) steric packing in active sites of enzymes. Of further attention, would be to tune the acid-base transition properties of His. Indeed, the imidazole side chain seems to be optimized for various chemical transformations at physiological pH, due to its close to neutral pKa. It is also well-known that imidazole is not interchangeable with other naturally occurring heterocycles, thiazole and oxazole, without adverse effects on enzyme activity due to different basicity values (Fig. 9A). By far, some His analogues with altered pKa profiles (e.g. 1,2,4-triazole-3-alanine, 4-fluorohistidine and 2-fluorohistidine) have been incorporated into proteins by SPI. [176] Recently, Schultz an co-workers [109] evolved a PylRS-based amber suppressor o-pair for a series of histidine analogues in both Escherichia coli and mammalian cells (such as the ones shown on Fig. 9B). Subsequently His66 in the blue fluorescent protein (BFP) was substituted with these histidine analogues giving rise to variants with unique 10.1002/anie.201610129 REVIEW spectroscopic features. We foresee that engineering histidine side chains will soon contribute to a better understanding of the role of imidazole heterocycle in catalytic transformations and could yield a convenient strategy to improve enzymatic activity, as well as change the pH profiles of the existing biocatalysts. The two strategies for incorporation of ncAAs, SPI and SCS, provide a means to substitute canonical residues by structurally similar (analogues) or dissimilar (surrogates) noncanonical ones. Combining SPI and SCS might as well become a strong approach for the development of new biocatalysts. For example, Hoesl and Budisa demonstrated that in TTL it was indeed possible to combine an increase in enzyme activity achieved by global Nle incorporation with site-specific incorporation of the photo-crosslinking amino acid para-benzoylphenylalanine (Bpa). [77] Similarly, variants with elevated enzyme activity could be endowed with bioorthogonal conjugation groups to perform immobilization via click chemistry. Likewise, Deepankumar et al. combined SPI and SCS to render a more stable ω-TA that could be additionally immobilized to chitosan and polystyrene for multiple reaction cycles. [111] Global ncAA incorporation by SPI requires only a single expression experiment that can be quickly performed. The bottleneck of the SPI method is the bioavailability of the ncAAs for target protein expression. To assure sufficient intracellular concentrations, the ncAA analogues are supplied in excess in the culture and this may become expensive, in particular for scale-up fermentations. However, this issue was recently addressed by engineering the expression host with metabolic pathways for the intracellular production of ncAAs. [44,75,88] Similarly, E. coli strains have been engineered for the SCS production of proteins containing Tyr [177] , Phe [178] and Pyl [179] analogues. Doubtless, an expanded genetic code in combination with metabolic engineering would further diversify the chemical arsenal for the large-scale production of useful xenoproteins, which are today still the exclusive domain of proof-of-principle experiments.

On the other hand, the main issue limiting SCS application is probably the low incorporation efficiency depending on the target site. This point has been addressed by directed evolution. [76] In one of the first studies, Baldwin et al. identified multiple permissive sites for ncAA incorporation into a protein by randomly inserting stop codons along the gene sequence. [180] In another work, Cropp and colleagues [181] tested the incorporation of a single ncAA at different positions along a target protein sequence by creating a library of mutants, containing one in-frame amber stop codon each. This method took the name of Scanning Unnatural Amino Acids Mutagenesis (SUAAM).
