Shortly after, the group extended the method by allowing the inframe mutation of one, two or three consecutive codons for Multicodon Scanning Mutagenesis (MSM). [182] However, all the aforementioned methods do not allow the controlled insertion of TAG codons, which can render the library creation timeexpensive. To circumvent these drawbacks, Magliery and colleagues [183] developed a Stop Codon Scanning Mutagenesis (SCSM) method that allows the specific insertion of in-frame stop codons during DNA synthesis by using protected nucleotide phosphoramidites. The method was successfully applied to incorporate Bpa into a model protein.

The Schultz lab also combined SCS with directed evolution in the form of saturation mutagenesis to optimize antibodies containing sulfotyrosine (STyr, SY), with binding affinities higher than those conferred by the 20 cAAs. [184] All these examples clearly illustrate how the combination of directed evolution and genetic-code engineering will further increase the chemical functionality of proteins and enzymes, thus complementing the standard cAA based with an ncAA based protein-engineering toolbox (Fig. 1).

div.head: Summary and Outlook
div.p: Importantly, XB complements directed evolution because ncAAbased protein engineering aims to provide unnatural building blocks and cofactors whose chemistry could offer advantages not conferred by the twenty cAAs for applications in biocatalysis and beyond. For example, various ncAAs with electron rich aromatic side chains such as aniline, aminophenol, catechols, azidophenols which are especially useful in oxidative couplings of enzymes [185] or in enzyme catalysis where aromatic πelectrons play an essential role [186] can be introduced directly using both SCS and SPI. A diverse toolkit of ncAAs (Fig. 4) has been developed offering unique functionalities such as photoswitches, novel spectroscopic probes, moieties capable of orthogonal chemical reactivity, redox activity, and metal ion binding or novel steric properties. The corresponding methodologies for incorporation of maximal ncAA numbers in maximal combinations are also provided at least for the overexpression of biocatalysts in common workhorses such as E. coli (Fig. 1). This toolkit will be very useful in increasing our understanding of how protein architecture imposes specific electrostatic fields onto bound substrates, i.e., to quantify their magnitude and catalytic effects (Fig. 7 and 8). NcAAs with physicochemical properties different from those of the native residues not only provide insights into enzyme activity and stability, but also improve these features by adding unconventional moieties at key positions. Additionally, the employment of ncAAs will also allow very efficient and controllable conjugation of enzymes on solid supports as well as the introduction of unnatural metal cofactors (Scheme 17 and Fig. 9). Nonetheless, further development of innovative methodologies for library design, screening, genetic selection and metabolic engineering are necessary to enable a wider use of ncAAs. Only with cheap and reproducible technology at hand we will be able to explore whether ncAAs can create more active, specific, stable and chemically functionalised enzymes by expanding the amino acid pool beyond the 20 cAAs. These efforts will also 10.1002/anie.201610129 provide deeper insights into protein evolution. We expect that further efforts in XB will notably increase the application of unnatural building blocks in biocatalysis.

div.head: REVIEW Entry for the Table of Contents
REVIEW
div.p: Xenobiology aims to design biological systems endowed with unusual biochemistries, for instance, by engineering the genetic code with unnatural amino acids and cofactors, the design of enzymes endowed with unique properties that can be used as useful biocatalysts.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 1. Waves in the biocatalysis field and the modern protein-engineering toolbox. The development of biocatalysis in the last decades is exemplified here by the evolution of cytochrome P450 monooxygenase-based oxidations.The regio-and stereosectivity of the newly introduced hydroxylßgroups are marked in red on the presented structures. The first engineering wave started early in the last century when it was realized that whole-cell or cell lysates from organisms such as fungi could catalyze important chemical biotransformations like steroid hydroxylation.[3] In the second wave, the rise of molecular biology and employment of tools in microbiology enabled a more precise control of protein function, as exemplified by the site-directed mutagenesis of a mouse CYP for the hydroxylation of steroids.[4] At the beginning of the third wave, control over stereo-and regioselectivity via directed evolution was achieved, as illustrated by the ISM-based CASTing of Cytochrome P450 derived from Bacillus megaterium (P450BM3) towards testosterone hydroxylation.[15] Currently, the third wave is dedicated to the optimization of virtually any biocatalyst to fit the process specifications, as well as the creation of enzymes that do not exist in nature using de novo design and directed evolution. ISM[16] : iterative saturation mutagenesis; CAST[17] : combinatorial active site saturation test; B-FIT: B-factors iterative test; ProSAR: statistical analysis of protein sequence activity relationships[18] ; MDs: molecular dynamics simulations; QM/MM: quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics; SPI: Selective-pressure incorporation and SCS: Stop codon suppression of ncAAs: non-canonical amino acids.

figure.head: Nediljko
figure.figDesc: Budisa has been Professor of Biocatalysis at TU Berlin since 2010. He received his PhD degree in 1997 and has done pioneering work in genetic-code engineering and most recently in chemical synthetic biology (Xenobiology). His research focuses primarily on the development of in vivo methods for introducing geneticallyencoded protein modifications in individual proteins, complex protein structures and whole proteomes.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 3. The genetic code in a radial representation. Chart from inside to outside: an mRNA triplet (5'-3') is assigned to one of the 20 canonical amino acids or a stop codon. The natural expansion of the genetic code that includes selenocystein (SeC) at opal stop codon (UGA) and pyrrolysine (Pyl) at the amber stop codon (UAG) is depicted.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 4. Survey of ncAAs employed to tune enzymatic properties. The numerals following the abbreviated ncAA names indicate the relevant subsections of part 3 of this review: 1, activity, including turnover number and catalytic efficiency; 2, stability, including extending the storage half-life and resistance to oxidation, organic solvents, denaturants, inhibitors, and heat denaturation; 3, expanding the substrate scope or changing enantio-and stereospecificity; 4, eliminating inhibition mechanisms; 5, inserting reactive groups and bioorthogonal handles useful for surface immobilization; 6, investigation of enzyme electrostatics within protein structures and over the course of catalysis, and; 7, enabling metal-coordination or the binding of unnatural cofactors. See also Table1.
